definition: Chemical elements that typically lack metallic properties like conductivity and luster, often forming covalent bonds and existing as gases or brittle solids.

positive_examples: The nitrogen in the air we breathe makes up most of our atmosphere.
Oxygen is essential for combustion and cellular respiration.
Carbon forms the backbone of all organic molecules in living things.
Phosphorus is a key component in DNA and energy storage molecules.
Sulfur gives rotten eggs their distinctive smell when it forms hydrogen sulfide.
Selenium is used in photocells because its conductivity changes with light.
negative_examples: Iron rusts when exposed to moisture and oxygen over time.
The copper wiring conducts electricity throughout the building efficiently.
Gold maintains its lustrous appearance even after centuries of exposure.
Aluminum foil reflects heat and light due to its metallic surface.
The steel beam provides structural support due to its strength.
Silver jewelry tarnishes when exposed to sulfur compounds in air.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: Metals, Metalloids, AlkaliMetals, TransitionMetals
